title: Boris Johnson given deadline by French president to compromise on Brexit plans
text:

Boris Johnson was tonight given a deadline of Friday by French President Emmanuel Macron to compromise on his Brexit plans.

The Prime Minister has doubled down on his No Deal rhetoric after EU leaders all but dismissed his “two borders” proposal for Ireland as unworkable.

He insisted on Sunday that the UK would pack its bags and leave on October 31 despite MPs bringing in a law to stop it.

“The only question is whether Brussels cheerily waves us off with a mutually agreeable deal, or whether we will be forced to head off on our own,” he said.

But in a phone call last night in which the PM presented his proposals for a new deal, President Macron urged him to compromise further.

And he signalled that EU chiefs would decide by Friday whether the UK had moved enough to strike a deal.

A French Government official said: “The President told him that the negotiations should continue swiftly with Michel Barnier’s team in coming days, in order to evaluate at the end of the week whether a deal is possible that respects European Union principles.”

The PM will talk to more EU leaders today while his top Brexit advisor David Frost and Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay will spend the week on a whirlwind tour of European capitals.

A senior No 10 source said: “The UK has made a big, important offer but it’s time for the Commission to show a willingness to compromise too. If not the UK will leave with no deal”.

(Image: ANGELO CARCONI/EPA-EFE/REX)

Earlier, Mr Barclay suggested the UK could show some flexibility over controversial plans to give Northern Ireland a veto over an all-island regulatory system after Brexit.

He told the BBC: “The key is the principle of consent. Now, of course in the mechanism as part of the intensive negotiations we can look at that and discuss that.”

No 10 is understood to be planning to blame the EU for any delay if the PM ends up breaking his “do or die” Brexit pledge.

Mr Barnier said: “These negotiations have been lose-lose since the beginning. We are ready for a no-deal, even if we do not want it... If that happens, it would be the choice of the United Kingdom.”

EU insiders remained downbeat about the prospects of the UK moving enough to reach a deal - and fully expect Mr Johnson’s new proposal to be formally rejected this week.

Latvian PM Krišjānis Kariņš claimed it was now “a bit of a long shot” to get a deal done before October 31.

Scotland’s highest civil court is today [MON] expected to rule on what sanctions could be imposed on the PM if he fails to comply with the Benn Act to ask for a Brexit delay.

Mr Johnson has insisted that he will abide by the law - but has also said he will deliver Brexit come what may.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

Shadow Attorney General Shami Chakrabarti claimed he was “speaking with forked tongue” by saying two different things at the same time.

Government sources said that Attorney General Geoffrey Cox has threatened to quit if Mr Johnson refuses to write a letter asking the EU to delay Brexit.

Mr Barclay confirmed the Government has been talking to Labour MPs with Leave seats about voting for any deal that is agreed with the EU.

It comes amid speculation that Mr Johnson could offer MPs a vote on his plans before a crucial Brussels in 10 days time - even though Parliament could amend the plans.

Labour MP Lisa Nandy said up to 40 Labour MPs could vote for a Brexit deal, but that she would not support the current proposals.

But senior Labour insiders think that the number is closer to a dozen, amid concern Mr Johnson could then go on to rip up workers’ rights and other standards.

Ms Nandy added: “It’s deeply frustrating that for all of this talk about getting Brexit done, he doesn’t seem to be serious at all about trying to agree a cross-party deal and move us forwards”.

(Image: PA)

Another MP approached by one “rude and undiplomatic” Cabinet minister told the Mirror that he had demonstrated “poor judgement and failure to actually listen”.

Mr Johnson could be forced by MPs to publish the full legal text of his new proposals today in a move spearheaded by shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer.

Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell has ruled out Labour backing anybody but Jeremy Corbyn as a caretaker leader to ask for a Brexit extension - even though the Lib Dems said they wouldn’t support him.

And Buckingham Palace insiders said the prospect of the Queen sacking the PM if he refused to leave No 10 after losing a no confidence vote was “frankly unthinkable”.

But they added that the move would be “hugely frowned upon” by the Palace.

Downing Street said the PM had told Mr Macron “we have to push forward”, adding the EU “should no be lured into the mistaken belief” that the UK would stay beyond October 31.

“The PM said that this is the final opportunity to secure a deal . . . but if this is to be possible, the EU must match the compromises that the UK has made in recent weeks and months,” it added.
description: Emmanuel Macron urged him to compromise further and said the EU would decide whether the UK had moved enough to strike a deal
